title: A Single-Center, Randomized, Double-Blinded, Placebo-Controlled, 4-way Cross-over Study to Assess the Effect of a Single Oral Dose of AZD3293 Administration on QTc Interval Compared to Placebo, Using Open-Label AVELOX (Moxifloxacin) as a Positive Control, in Healthy Male Subjects
description_brief: A thorough QT study of AZD3293
description_detailed: A Single-Center, Randomized, Double-Blinded, Placebo-Controlled, 4-way Cross-over Study to Assess the Effect of a Single Oral Dose of AZD3293 Administration on QTc Interval Compared to Placebo, Using Open-Label AVELOX (moxifloxacin) as a Positive Control, in Healthy Male Subjects
explanation_target: Reason: The trial is a thorough QT study administering a single oral dose of AZD3293 vs placebo (with moxifloxacin as positive control) in healthy male subjects — the goal is to assess QTc effects of the investigational drug (trial description provided by user).

Act: AZD3293 is an oral, potent BACE1 (β‑secretase) inhibitor developed for Alzheimer’s disease; it is a small‑molecule that reduces production of amyloid‑β peptides and has been advanced into late‑stage clinical trials (also known as lanabecestat, LY3314814). citeturn0search4turn0search8turn0search1

Supporting web search results (selected): - AZD3293 characterized as a potent, orally active BACE1 inhibitor in the Journal of Alzheimer’s Disease (preclinical pharmacology and BBB penetration). citeturn0search4 - Lanabecestat (AZD3293; LY3314814) described as an oral BACE1 inhibitor with Phase 1/2/3 development and effects on CSF Aβ; safety/PK reports in PubMed. citeturn0search8turn0search3 - Lilly/AstraZeneca press release announcing Fast Track designation and Phase 2/3 development for AZD3293 (lanabecestat). citeturn0search1

Reflect: By the category definitions provided, AZD3293 is a disease‑targeted small molecule (it is a small‑molecule BACE inhibitor targeting Alzheimer’s amyloid pathology). There is no ambiguity in the mechanism from available sources; therefore the correct classification is 'disease-targeted small molecule'. citeturn0search4turn0search8
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug AZD3293 (lanabecestat, LY3314814) is a small‑molecule inhibitor of BACE1 (β‑secretase), an enzyme that cleaves APP to generate amyloid‑β peptides—therefore the biological focus of the intervention is the amyloid‑β production pathway, which maps to CADRO category A) Amyloid beta. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Act: Extracted details from the trial description and literature: AZD3293 (lanabecestat, LY3314814) is an orally active, blood–brain barrier‑penetrant BACE1 inhibitor developed for Alzheimer’s disease that reduces CSF and plasma Aβ (amyloid‑β) species; the provided trial is a QTc (safety) study in healthy subjects but the drug’s mechanism is clearly BACE inhibition (amyloid production reduction). Based on this mechanism the appropriate CADRO assignment is A) Amyloid beta. citeturn0search4turn0search6

Reflect: The classification was checked against CADRO definitions—BACE1 inhibition is an upstream anti‑amyloid strategy (targets production of Aβ rather than tau, inflammation, synaptic function, etc.). The trial itself is a safety (QT) study rather than an efficacy trial, but that does not change the drug’s mechanistic target. There is no evidence in the description that multiple distinct CADRO targets are intended, so R) Multi‑target is not appropriate. Therefore A) Amyloid beta is the best fit. citeturn0search2

Supporting web search results (selected): - PubMed / Journal article: Phase 1 study reporting pharmacokinetics and effects of lanabecestat (AZD3293; LY3314814) on plasma and CSF Aβ peptides. citeturn0search1 - ALZFORUM entry summarizing lanabecestat (AZD3293) as a BACE inhibitor (development history, mechanism). citeturn0search2 - Preclinical/compound profiles and pharmacology summarizing AZD3293 potency and Aβ lowering in vivo. citeturn0search4 - Clinical pharmacology article describing tablet formulation, PK, and robust reduction of Aβ species with lanabecestat. citeturn0search6
